case.name: Travelex Limited v Commissioner of Taxation (Corrigendum dated 4 February 2009) [2008] FCA 1961 (19 December 2008)

citphrases.citphrase: whether full input tax credits available to taxpayer
taxpayer acquired services in a taxable supply by way of a feasibility study as to whether it should acquire debts and recover them
taxpayer carrying on enterprise of acquiring debts and recovering them, acquisition of debts a financial supply
taxpayer also acquired services relating to recovery of debts
whether input credits disallowed as relating to the making of a financial supply (the acquisition of the debts) which would be input taxed

whether credits disallowed where acquisition of recovery services related to the financial supply (the acquisition of the debts) a new tax system (goods and services tax) act 1999 (cth), ss 11 -15(2)(a), 11 -5, 11 -20, div 132 a new tax system (goods and services tax) regulations 1999 (cth), regs 70-5.02, 40-5.09
banking (foreign exchange) regulations , regs 6, 42. constitutional law (cth)
law prohibiting taking australian currency or foreign currency out of australia
a new tax system (goods and services tax) act 1999
conversion of australian dollars into foreign currency for use outside australia
whether transaction a "supply in relation to rights"

citances.sentence:
At first instance, Emmett J concluded [13] that the rights which are the incidents of being the holder or owner of bank notes issued by a foreign country "are not relevantly connected with the supply constituted by the ... currency transaction, such that it can be said that the supply of the bank notes was a supply made in relation to those so-called rights". There is not a supply "in relation to rights" "where the supply of rights is merely integral, ancillary or incidental to another dominant part of the supply, the supply being characterised by the dominant part" [7] . The appellant, however, put an alternative submission: that whether or not the Fijian bank notes had the characteristics of promissory notes, the Reserve Bank of Fiji Act 1983 (Fiji), ss 22, 24, 26 and 27, endowed their possessors with equivalent rights [30] . Emmett J concluded [6] that there could be a supply "in relation to rights" only "if the essential character or substance of the supply, or of a separately identifiable part of the supply, is one of rights". " [43] In the Full Court, Stone J and Edmonds J, for reasons which differed in some respects, agreed generally with the primary judge. At first instance, Emmett J rejected Travelex's arguments and dismissed [5] the proceeding. This submission appealed to the trial judge, who said that the rights which the holder of the Fijian bank notes had could not be said [33] :
"to be the subject of any transfer or assignment by Travelex, merely because they are incidents that pass with ownership or possession of the bank notes. Rather, as noted earlier, Emmett J identified [14] the supply as "a supply of the physical notes", and concluded that "[t]he incidents of being the holder or owner of those bank notes were simply the consequences of becoming holder or owner". A supply that does not bind the parties in some way was said [25] to be "not a supply that is made in relation to rights". At first instance, Emmett J distinguished between rights that are "the essential character or substance of the supply, or of a separately identifiable part of the supply" and those that are "merely integral, ancillary or incidental to another dominant part of the supply" [24] .

28 This appeal raises a question of construction in relation to the A New Tax System (Goods and Services Tax) Act 1999 (Cth) ( GST Act) . The facts which give rise to this question are not in dispute. They are as deposed to in an affidavit made on 21 December 2007 by Mr Geoffrey Urquhart, an employee of the appellant, and as set out fully in [2]-[7] of the reasons of the primary judge; Travelex Limited v Commissioner of Taxation [2008] FCA 1961. For present purposes a brief account will suffice.
